theorem calculus_135282 :
  Tendsto (λ x => ((1 + x * 2^x) / (1 + x * 3^x)) ^ (1 / x^2)) (𝓝[≠] 0) (𝓝 (2/3)) :=

soln_description:
Answer: 212 For more information, see the Wikipedia entry at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ RSA_Factoring_Challenge.
RSA-640 was factored in November 2005, and the effort took approximately $302.2 \mathrm{GHz}$-Opteron-CPU years over five months of calendar time.
informal_statement: 35. NUMB3RS. The RSA Factoring Challenge, which ended in 2007, challenged computational mathematicians to factor extremely large numbers that were the product of two prime numbers. The largest number successfully factored in this challenge was RSA-640, which has 193 decimal digits and carried a prize of $\$ 20,000$. The next challenge number carried prize of $\$ 30,000$, and contains $N$ decimal digits. Your task is to submit a guess for $N$. Only the team(s) that have the closest guess(es) receives points. If $k$ teams all have the closest guesses, then each of them receives $\left\lceil\frac{20}{k}\right\rceil$ points.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 35. NUMB3RS. The RSA Factoring Challenge, which ended in 2007, challenged computational mathematicians to factor extremely large numbers that were the product of two prime numbers. The largest number successfully factored in this challenge was RSA-640, which has 193 decimal digits and carried a prize of $\$ 20,000$. The next challenge number carried prize of $\$ 30,000$, and contains $N$ decimal digits. Your task is to submit a guess for $N$. Only the team(s) that have the closest guess(es) receives points. If $k$ teams all have the closest guesses, then each of them receives $\left\lceil\frac{20}{k}\right\rceil$ points. -/
theorem number_theory_153795 (n : ℕ) (h : n > 0) :
    n = 212 := by

soln_description:
## Subject II

Since $F$ is the primitive of $f$, $f(x) = F'(x) = \frac{f(x) + x f'(x)}{2}, \forall x \in \mathbf{R}$.

It follows that $2 f(x) = f(x) + x f'(x)$, hence $f(x) - x f'(x) = 0, \forall x \in \mathbf{R}$.

If $x \in \mathbf{R} \backslash \{0\}, \frac{f(x) - x f'(x)}{x^2} = 0$, which means $\left(\frac{f(x)}{x}\right)' = 0 \forall x \in \mathbf{R} \backslash \{0\}$.

It follows that there exist $c_1, c_2 \in \mathbf{R}$, such that $\frac{f(x)}{x} = c_1, \forall x > 0$.

Then $f(x) = \begin{cases} c_1 x, & x > 0 \\ c_2 x, & x < 0 \end{cases}$

From the conditions that $f$ is continuous and differentiable on $\mathbf{R}$, it follows that $c_1 = c_2 = c \in \mathbf{R}$ and $a = 0$.

Then $f(x) = c x, \forall x \in \mathbf{R}$. $1 \text{p}$
informal_statement:
## Subject II

Determine $f: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}, f$ differentiable, knowing that $f$ admits a primitive $F: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$, with the property that $F(x)=\frac{x f(x)}{2}$, for any $x \in \mathbf{R}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Subject II

Determine $f: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}, f$ differentiable, knowing that $f$ admits a primitive $F: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$, with the property that $F(x)=\frac{x f(x)}{2}$, for any $x \in \mathbf{R}$. -/
theorem calculus_118894 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : Differentiable ℝ f)
    (F : ℝ → ℝ) (hF : ∀ x, F x = (x * f x) / 2) :
    ∀ x, f x = 0 := by

soln_description:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 2 \pi}(\cos x)^{\frac{\operatorname{ctg} 2 x}{\sin 3 x}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 2 \pi}\left(e^{\ln (\cos x)}\right)^{\frac{\operatorname{ctg} 2 x}{\sin 3 x}}=$

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 2 \pi} e^{\frac{\operatorname{ctg} 2 x}{\sin 3 x} \cdot \ln (\cos x)}=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 2 \pi} \frac{\operatorname{ctg} 2 x}{\sin 3 x} \cdot \ln (\cos x)\right\}=$

Substitution:

$x=y+2 \pi \Rightarrow y=x-2 \pi$

$x \rightarrow 2 \pi \Rightarrow y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\operatorname{ctg} 2(y+2 \pi)}{\sin 3(y+2 \pi)} \cdot \ln (\cos (y+2 \pi))\right\}=$

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\operatorname{ctg}(2 y+4 \pi)}{\sin (3 y+6 \pi)} \cdot \ln (\cos y)\right\}=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\operatorname{ctg} 2 y}{\sin 3 y} \cdot \ln \left(1-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{y}{2}\right)\right\}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} 2 y \cdot \sin 3 y} \cdot \ln \left(1-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{y}{2}\right)\right\}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\operatorname{tg} 2 y \sim 2 y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(2 y \rightarrow 0)$

$\sin 3 y \sim 3 y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(3 y \rightarrow 0)$

$\ln \left(1-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{y}{2}\right) \sim-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{y}{2}$, as $y \rightarrow 0\left(-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{y}{2} \rightarrow 0\right)$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{2 y \cdot 3 y} \cdot\left(-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{y}{2}\right)\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$$
\sin \frac{y}{2} \sim \frac{y}{2}, \text{ as } y \rightarrow 0\left(\frac{y}{2} \rightarrow 0\right)
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{3 y^{2}} \cdot\left(-\left(\frac{y}{2}\right)^{2}\right)\right\}=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{3 y^{2}} \cdot\left(-\frac{y^{2}}{4}\right)\right\}= \\
& =\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}-\frac{1}{12}\right\}=e^{-\frac{1}{12}}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Limits 19-9
informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 2 \pi}(\cos x)^{\frac{\operatorname{ctg} 2 x}{\sin 3 x}}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the limit of the function:

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 2 \pi}(\cos x)^{\frac{\operatorname{ctg} 2 x}{\sin 3 x}}$ -/
theorem calculus_130935 :
  Tendsto (λ x => (Real.cos x) ^ (1 / Real.tan (2 * x) / Real.sin (3 * x))) (𝓝[≠] (2 * Real.pi)) (𝓝 (Real.exp (-1 / 12))) := by

soln_description:
7.36 Here

$3^{x}-5^{2-x}>0$.

Let's use the fact that $2-x=\log _{5} 5^{2-x}$, and write the equation in the form

$\log _{5}\left(2^{3} \cdot 5^{2-x}\right)=\log _{5}\left(3^{x}-5^{2-x}\right)$

Then we have

$2^{3} \cdot 5^{2-x}=3^{x}-5^{2-x} ; 5^{2-x}\left(2^{3}+1\right)=3^{x} ; 5^{2-x}=3^{x-2}$.

Finally, multiplying both sides of the equation by $3^{2-x} \neq 0$, we get

$(5 \cdot 3)^{2-x}=1 \Rightarrow 15^{2-x}=15^{0} \Rightarrow 2-x=0 \Rightarrow x=2$.

This root satisfies the inequality (1).

Answer: $x=2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $7.36 \quad 3 \log _{5} 2+2-x=\log _{5}\left(3^{x}-5^{2-x}\right)$.

$7.37 \quad 25^{\log _{2} \sqrt{x+3}-0.5 \log _{2}\left(x^{2}-9\right)}=\sqrt{2(7-x)}$. -/
theorem algebra_179867 (x : ℝ) (hx : x ≠ 0) (h : 3 * Real.logb 5 2 + 2 - x = Real.logb 5 (3 ^ x - 5 ^ (2 - x))) :
    25 ^ (Real.logb 2 (Real.sqrt (x + 3)) - 0.5 * Real.logb 2 (x ^ 2 - 9)) = Real.sqrt (2 * (7 - x)) ↔ x = 2 := by

soln_description:
3. We first prove the following lemma.
Lemma. For $d, c \in \mathbb{N}$ and $d^{2} \mid c^{2}+1$ there exists $b \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $d^{2}\left(d^{2}+1\right) \mid b^{2}+1$
Proof. It is enough to set $b=c+d^{2} c-d^{3}=c+d^{2}(c-d)$.

Using the lemma it suffices to find increasing sequences $d_{n}$ and $c_{n}$ such that $c_{n}-d_{n}$ is an increasing sequence and $d_{n}^{2} \mid c_{n}^{2}+1$. We then obtain the desired sequences $a_{n}$ and $b_{n}$ from $a_{n}=d_{n}^{2}$ and $b_{n}=c_{n}+d_{n}^{2}\left(c_{n}-d_{n}\right)$. It is easy to check that $d_{n}=2^{2 n}+1$ and $c_{n}=2^{n d_{n}}$ satisfy the required conditions. Hence we have demonstrated the existence of increasing sequences $a_{n}$ and $b_{n}$ such that $a_{n}\left(a_{n}+1\right) \mid b_{n}^{2}+1$.
Remark. There are many solutions to this problem. For example, it is sufficient to prove that the Pell-type equation $5 a_{n}\left(a_{n}+1\right)=b_{n}^{2}+1$ has an infinity of solutions in positive integers. Alternatively, one can show that $a_{n}\left(a_{n}+1\right)$ can be represented as a sum of two coprime squares for infinitely many $a_{n}$, which implies the existence of $b_{n}$.
informal_statement: 3. N3 (RUS) Prove that there exist two strictly increasing sequences $\left(a_{n}\right)$ and ( $\left.b_{n}\right)$ such that $a_{n}\left(a_{n}+1\right)$ divides $b_{n}^{2}+1$ for every natural number $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. N3 (RUS) Prove that there exist two strictly increasing sequences $\left(a_{n}\right)$ and ( $\left.b_{n}\right)$ such that $a_{n}\left(a_{n}+1\right)$ divides $b_{n}^{2}+1$ for every natural number $n$. -/
theorem number_theory_262974 :
    ∃ a b : ℕ → ℕ,
      StrictMono a ∧
      StrictMono b ∧
      ∀ n, a n * (a n + 1) ∣ b n ^ 2 + 1 := by

soln_description: 13.19. Let $\boldsymbol{a}=\overrightarrow{A B}, \boldsymbol{b}=\overrightarrow{B C}$ and $\boldsymbol{c}=\overrightarrow{C D}$. Then $\overrightarrow{A D}=\boldsymbol{a}+\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{c}, \overrightarrow{A C}=\boldsymbol{a}+\boldsymbol{b}$ and $\overrightarrow{B D}=\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{c}$. It is also clear that $|\boldsymbol{a}|^{2}+|\boldsymbol{b}|^{2}+|\boldsymbol{c}|^{2}+|\boldsymbol{a}+\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{c}|^{2}-|\boldsymbol{a}+\boldsymbol{b}|^{2}-|\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{c}|^{2}=$ $=|\boldsymbol{a}|^{2}+2(\boldsymbol{a}, \boldsymbol{c})+|\boldsymbol{c}|^{2}=|\boldsymbol{a}+\boldsymbol{c}|^{2} \geqslant 0$. Equality is achieved only if $\boldsymbol{a}=-\boldsymbol{c}$, i.e., $A B C D$ is a parallelogram.
informal_statement: 13.19. Given points $A, B, C$ and $D$. Prove that $A B^{2}+B C^{2}+C D^{2}+$ $+D A^{2} \geqslant A C^{2}+B D^{2}$, and equality is achieved if and only if $A B C D$ is a parallelogram.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- 13.19. Given points $A, B, C$ and $D$. Prove that $A B^{2}+B C^{2}+C D^{2}+$ $+D A^{2} \geqslant A C^{2}+B D^{2}$, and equality is achieved if and only if $A B C D$ is a parallelogram. -/
theorem inequalities_109604 (A B C D : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) :
  dist A B^2 + dist B C^2 + dist C D^2 + dist D A^2 ≥ dist A C^2 + dist B D^2 ∧
  (dist A B^2 + dist B C^2 + dist C D^2 + dist D A^2 = dist A C^2 + dist B D^2 ↔
    ∃ P Q R S : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2),
      A = P ∧ B = Q ∧ C = R ∧ D = S ∧
      dist P Q = dist R S ∧
      dist Q R = dist P S) :=

soln_description:
4. $\left[-\frac{5}{2}, 10\right)$.

It is clear that $\sin x \neq 0, \cos x \neq 0$. Thus, $x \neq \frac{k \pi}{2}(k \in \mathbb{Z})$. Therefore, $\cos 4 x \in[-1,1)$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Hence } y=\frac{\sin 9 x}{\sin x}+\frac{\cos 9 x}{\cos x} \\
=2 \cos 8 x+\sin 8 x\left(\frac{\cos x}{\sin x}-\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}\right) \\
=2\left(\cos 8 x+\sin 8 x \cdot \frac{\cos 2 x}{\sin 2 x}\right) \\
=2\left(2 \cos ^{2} 4 x-1+4 \cos 4 x \cdot \cos ^{2} 2 x\right) \\
=2\left(4 \cos ^{2} 4 x+2 \cos 4 x-1\right) \\
=8\left(\cos 4 x+\frac{1}{4}\right)^{2}-\frac{5}{2} \in\left[-\frac{5}{2}, 10\right) .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: 4. The range of the function $y^{\prime}=\frac{\sin 9 x}{\sin x}+\frac{\cos 9 x}{\cos x}$ is
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 4. The range of the function $y^{\prime}=\frac{\sin 9 x}{\sin x}+\frac{\cos 9 x}{\cos x}$ is -/
theorem algebra_326145 (f : ℝ → ℝ)
  (hf : f = λ x => sin (9 * x) / sin x + cos (9 * x) / cos x) :
  range f = {y | -5 / 2 ≤ y ∧ y < 10} :=

soln_description:
$$
\left\{\frac{3^{l}}{10^{4}}\right\}=\left\{\frac{3^{m}}{10^{4}}\right\}=\left\{\frac{3^{n}}{10^{4}}\right\} \Leftrightarrow 3^{l} \equiv 3^{m} \equiv 3^{n}\left(\bmod 10^{4}\right),
$$

and $3^{m} \equiv 3^{n}\left(\bmod 10^{4}\right) \Leftrightarrow 3^{m-n} \equiv 1\left(\bmod 10^{4}\right) \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}3^{m-n} \equiv 1(\bmod 16) \\ 3^{m-n} \equiv 1(\bmod 256)\end{array}\right.$
Since $\delta_{16}(3)=4$, then $3^{x} \equiv 1(\bmod 16) \Rightarrow 4 \mid x$;
Let $\delta_{625}(3)=t$, then $t \mid \varphi(625)=500$. On the other hand,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
3^{50} \equiv(6561 \cdot 9)^{5} \equiv 59049^{5} \equiv(-326)^{5} \equiv(106276)^{2}(-326) \equiv(26)^{2}(-326) \\
\equiv 51(-326) \equiv-16626 \equiv-376 \equiv 249(\bmod 625) \\
3^{250} \equiv 126 \cdot 126 \cdot 249 \equiv 15876 \cdot 249 \equiv 251 \cdot 249 \equiv-1(\bmod 625)
\end{array}
$$

Then $t \nmid 100, t \nmid 250, t \mid 500$, i.e., $t=500$. Therefore, $3^{x} \equiv 1\left(\bmod 10^{4}\right) \Leftrightarrow 500 \mid x$.
Thus, $500|m-n, 500| l-m$, hence $m \geqslant 501, n \geqslant 1001, l \geqslant 1501$.
Therefore, the minimum perimeter of such a triangle is $501+1001+1501=3003$.
informal_statement: 2. Let the three sides of a triangle be integers $l, m, n$ and $l>m>n$. It is known that $\left\{\frac{3^{l}}{10^{4}}\right\}=\left\{\frac{3^{m}}{10^{4}}\right\}=\left\{\frac{3^{n}}{10^{4}}\right\}$, where $\{x\}=x-[x]$. Find the minimum perimeter of such a triangle.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Let the three sides of a triangle be integers $l, m, n$ and $l>m>n$. It is known that $\left\{\frac{3^{l}}{10^{4}}\right\}=\left\{\frac{3^{m}}{10^{4}}\right\}=\left\{\frac{3^{n}}{10^{4}}\right\}$, where $\{x\}=x-[x]$. Find the minimum perimeter of such a triangle. -/
theorem number_theory_138145 (l m n : ℕ) (h₀ : l > m ∧ m > n) (h₁ : 3^l % 10^4 = 3^m % 10^4)
    (h₂ : 3^m % 10^4 = 3^n % 10^4) :
    l + m + n = 3003 := by

soln_description:
To prove or disprove that \( S_{n+1} = S_n \) for some positive integer \( n \), we need to analyze the sum of the digits of powers of 2. Let's denote \( S(n) \) as the sum of the digits of \( 2^n \).

1. **Sum of Digits and Modulo 9:**
   The sum of the digits of a number \( x \) is congruent to \( x \mod 9 \). This is a consequence of the fact that \( 10 \equiv 1 \pmod{9} \). Therefore, for any integer \( x \), we have:
   \[
   S(x) \equiv x \pmod{9}
   \]

2. **Behavior of Powers of 2 Modulo 9:**
   We need to understand the behavior of \( 2^n \mod 9 \). Let's compute the first few powers of 2 modulo 9:
   \[
   \begin{align*}
   2^1 &\equiv 2 \pmod{9}, \\
   2^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{9}, \\
   2^3 &\equiv 8 \pmod{9}, \\
   2^4 &\equiv 7 \pmod{9}, \\
   2^5 &\equiv 5 \pmod{9}, \\
   2^6 &\equiv 1 \pmod{9}.
   \end{align*}
   \]
   Notice that \( 2^6 \equiv 1 \pmod{9} \). This implies that the powers of 2 repeat every 6 steps modulo 9.

3. **Implication for Sum of Digits:**
   Since \( 2^6 \equiv 1 \pmod{9} \), we have:
   \[
   2^{n+6} \equiv 2^n \pmod{9}
   \]
   This means that the sum of the digits of \( 2^{n+6} \) is congruent to the sum of the digits of \( 2^n \) modulo 9:
   \[
   S(2^{n+6}) \equiv S(2^n) \pmod{9}
   \]

4. **Non-Equality of \( S_{n+1} \) and \( S_n \):**
   To show that \( S_{n+1} \neq S_n \) for all \( n \), we need to show that the sum of the digits of \( 2^n \) and \( 2^{n+1} \) are not equal. Since \( 2^{n+1} = 2 \cdot 2^n \), the sum of the digits of \( 2^{n+1} \) is generally different from the sum of the digits of \( 2^n \).

5. **Conclusion:**
   Given that \( 2^6 \equiv 1 \pmod{9} \) and the periodicity of powers of 2 modulo 9, we can conclude that \( S_{n+1} \neq S_n \) for all \( n \). The sum of the digits of \( 2^n \) and \( 2^{n+1} \) cannot be equal because the multiplication by 2 changes the digit sum in a non-trivial way.

\[
\blacksquare
\]
informal_statement: Let $S_{n}$ be the sum of the digits of $2^n$. Prove or disprove that $S_{n+1}=S_{n}$ for some positive integer $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def S : ℕ → ℕ
| n => (Nat.digits 10 (2^n)).sum

/- Let $S_{n}$ be the sum of the digits of $2^n$. Prove or disprove that $S_{n+1}=S_{n}$ for some positive integer $n$. -/
theorem number_theory_75523 : ∃ n, 0 < n ∧ S (n + 1) = S n := by

informal_proof:
We want to find the remainder of the expression $S = (\sum_{k=1}^{2019} k^2) + (\sum_{k=1}^{4037} k)$ when divided by $1013$. We will compute each summation separately modulo $1013$.

First, let us evaluate the sum of squares, $S_1 = \sum_{k=1}^{2019} k^2$. We use the formula for the sum of the first $n$ squares: $\sum_{k=1}^{n} k^2 = \frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}$.
For $n = 2019$, we have:
$S_1 = \frac{2019(2019+1)(2 \cdot 2019+1)}{6} = \frac{2019 \cdot 2020 \cdot 4039}{6}$.

Since $2019$ is divisible by $3$ and $2020$ is divisible by $2$, the numerator is divisible by $6$. We can simplify the expression before performing modular arithmetic:
$S_1 = \frac{2019}{3} \cdot \frac{2020}{2} \cdot 4039 = 673 \cdot 1010 \cdot 4039$.

Now, we compute the value of this product modulo $1013$. We find the remainders of each factor when divided by $1013$:
*   $673 \equiv 673 \pmod{1013}$.
*   $1010 \equiv -3 \pmod{1013}$.
*   $4039 = 3 \cdot 1013 + 1000$, so $4039 \equiv 1000 \equiv -13 \pmod{1013}$.

Substituting these values, we get:
$S_1 \equiv 673 \cdot (-3) \cdot (-13) \pmod{1013}$
$S_1 \equiv 673 \cdot 39 \pmod{1013}$.

To compute $673 \cdot 39$:
$673 \cdot 39 = 26247$.
Now we find the remainder of $26247$ when divided by $1013$:
$26247 = 25 \cdot 1013 + 922$.
Thus, $S_1 \equiv 922 \pmod{1013}$.

Next, we evaluate the sum of integers, $S_2 = \sum_{k=1}^{4037} k$. We use the formula for the sum of the first $n$ integers: $\sum_{k=1}^{n} k = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}$.
For $n = 4037$, we have:
$S_2 = \frac{4037(4037+1)}{2} = \frac{4037 \cdot 4038}{2}$.

We simplify by dividing $4038$ by $2$:
$S_2 = 4037 \cdot 2019$.

Now, we compute this product modulo $1013$. We find the remainders of each factor:
*   $4037 = 3 \cdot 1013 + 998$, so $4037 \equiv 998 \equiv -15 \pmod{1013}$.
*   $2019 = 1 \cdot 1013 + 1006$, so $2019 \equiv 1006 \equiv -7 \pmod{1013}$.

Substituting these values, we get:
$S_2 \equiv (-15) \cdot (-7) \pmod{1013}$
$S_2 \equiv 105 \pmod{1013}$.

Finally, we find the total sum modulo $1013$:
$S = S_1 + S_2 \equiv 922 + 105 \pmod{1013}$
$S \equiv 1027 \pmod{1013}$.

Since $1027 = 1 \cdot 1013 + 14$, the remainder is $14$.
Therefore, $((\sum_{k=1}^{2019} k^2) + (\sum_{k=1}^{4037} k)) \pmod{1013} = 14$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the remainder when $({{1}^{2}}+{{2}^{2}}+{{3}^{2}}+\cdots +{{2019}^{2}})+(1+2+3+\cdots +4037)$ is divided by $1013$. -/
theorem number_theory_3380 : ((∑ i in Finset.range 2019, (i + 1)^2) + (∑ i in Finset.range 4037, (i + 1))) % 1013 = 14 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_3380 : ((∑ i in Finset.range 2019, (i + 1)^2) + (∑ i in Finset.range 4037, (i + 1))) % 1013 = 14 := by 
  native_decide

soln_description:
1. To prove the original inequality, it suffices to prove
$$\begin{array}{l}
a b(a+b)+b c(b+c)+c a(c+a)+2 \sqrt{a b^{2} c(a+b)(b+c)}+ \\
2 \sqrt{a b c^{2}(b+c)(a+c)}+2 \sqrt{a^{2} b c(a+b)(a+c)}> \\
(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)
\end{array}$$

i.e., $\square$
$$b \sqrt{a c(a+b)(b+c)}+c \sqrt{a b(b+c)(a+c)}+a \sqrt{b c(a+b)(a+c)}>a b c$$

By the Arithmetic Mean-Geometric Mean Inequality,
$$\text { the left side } \geqslant 3 \sqrt[3]{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}>3 a b c \geq a b c$$
informal_statement: 1. Prove that for any positive numbers $a, b, c$, we have $\sqrt{a b(a+b)}+\sqrt{b c(b+c)}$ $\sqrt{c a(c+a)}>\sqrt{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}$ (1990 All-Russian Mathematical Olympiad Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 1. Prove that for any positive numbers $a, b, c$, we have $\sqrt{a b(a+b)}+\sqrt{b c(b+c)}$ $\sqrt{c a(c+a)}>\sqrt{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}$ (1990 All-Russian Mathematical Olympiad Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_597062 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    sqrt (a * b * (a + b)) + sqrt (b * c * (b + c)) + sqrt (c * a * (c + a)) >
    sqrt ((a + b) * (b + c) * (c + a)) := by

soln_description:
Answer: 13,14

Solution. If the smallest possible natural numbers, i.e., the card numbers (from 1 to 12), were written on the cards, then their sum would be $1+2+...+12=78$. But the actual sum is 6 more. This means that some numbers are greater than their numbers. If the number on the sixth card is greater than 6, then the numbers on cards 7-12 are also greater, and at least 7 will be added to the sum of 78. Therefore, the number on the sixth card is 6. The number on the seventh card can be 7 (example: $1,2,3, \ldots 10,11,18$), or it can be 8 (example: $1,2,3,4,5,6,8,9,10,11,12,13$). The number 9 cannot be written, because then on each subsequent card, the number is at least 2 more than its number, and at least 12 will be added to the total sum.
informal_statement: 8.1 On 12 cards, different natural numbers are written, their sum is 84. Masha laid out the cards in ascending order. What can the sum of the numbers on the two middle cards be? Find all possible answers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8.1 On 12 cards, different natural numbers are written, their sum is 84. Masha laid out the cards in ascending order. What can the sum of the numbers on the two middle cards be? Find all possible answers. -/
theorem number_theory_154545 (a : Fin 12 → ℕ) (ha : ∑ i, a i = 84)
    (h : ∀ i j, i < j → a i < a j) :
    a 5 + a 6 = 13 ∨ a 5 + a 6 = 14 := by

soln_description:
12. All seven vendors sold apples at 1 cent for 7 pieces; in cases where fewer than seven apples remained, they were sold at 3 cents per piece. Thus, each vendor earned 20 cents. Without in any way disputing the ingenuity of this problem, I have always found its solution unsatisfactory due to its ambiguity, even if we assume that with such an eccentric method of trading, one can speak of a single "price" for apples. We could just as well assume that the vendors sell apples at one price but with different discounts; sell apples of different varieties at different prices; sell at one price per basket; sell by weight, while the apples are of different sizes; reduce the price for less fresh apples, etc.

In general, we can say that \(n\) vendors, who have \(n a+(n-1), n(a+b)+(n-2), n(a+2 b)+(n-3), \ldots\), \(n[a+b(n-1)]\) apples respectively, can sell them in bunches of \(n\) pieces for 1 cent, and the remaining apples for \(b\) cents each, and each of the vendors will earn \(a+b(n-1)\) cents. In the case of our problem, \(a=2, b=3, n=7\).
informal_statement: 12. Seven apple vendors. Seven vendors had 20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 120, and 140 apples respectively. They went to the market and sold all their apples at the same price, earning the same revenue. At what price did the vendors sell the apples?
informal_proof:
We are given the equation:
\[20x + 40x + 60x + 80x + 100x + 120x + 140x = 20 \cdot 20 + 40 \cdot 20 + 60 \cdot 20 + 80 \cdot 20 + 100 \cdot 20 + 120 \cdot 20 + 140 \cdot 20\]

We can simplify the left-hand side of the equation by factoring out the common term \(x\), which is justified by the distributive property of multiplication over addition:
\[ (20 + 40 + 60 + 80 + 100 + 120 + 140)x \]
Calculating the sum of the coefficients gives:
\[ 20 + 40 + 60 + 80 + 100 + 120 + 140 = 560 \]
Thus, the left-hand side simplifies to \(560x\).

Next, we simplify the right-hand side of the equation by factoring out the common term \(20\):
\[ (20 + 40 + 60 + 80 + 100 + 120 + 140) \cdot 20 \]
The sum of the numbers in the parenthesis is the same as before, which is \(560\).
Thus, the right-hand side simplifies to \(560 \cdot 20\).

By substituting these simplified expressions back into the original equation, we obtain:
\[ 560x = 560 \cdot 20 \]
Since \(560 \neq 0\), we can divide both sides of the equation by \(560\), which yields:
\[ x = 20 \]
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12. Seven apple vendors. Seven vendors had 20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 120, and 140 apples respectively. They went to the market and sold all their apples at the same price, earning the same revenue. At what price did the vendors sell the apples? -/
theorem algebra_259437 {x : ℝ} (hx : x ≠ 0) (h : 20 * x + 40 * x + 60 * x + 80 * x + 100 * x + 120 * x + 140 * x = 20 * 20 + 40 * 20 + 60 * 20 + 80 * 20 + 100 * 20 + 120 * 20 + 140 * 20) :
    x = 20 := by

informal_statement:
Example 5 (36th IMO Problem) Let $a>0, b>0, c>0, abc=1$, prove that:
$$
\frac{1}{a^{3}(b+c)}+\frac{1}{b^{3}(a+c)}+\frac{1}{c^{3}(a+b)} \geqslant \frac{3}{2} .
$$

import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Ring
import Mathlib.Tactic

/- Example 5 (36th IMO Problem) Let $a>0, b>0, c>0, abc=1$, prove that:
$$
\frac{1}{a^{3}(b+c)}+\frac{1}{b^{3}(a+c)}+\frac{1}{c^{3}(a+b)} \geqslant \frac{3}{2} .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_169529
  (a b c : ℝ)
  (h₀ : 0 < a)
  (h₁ : 0 < b)
  (h₂ : 0 < c)
  (h₃ : a * b * c = 1) :
  3 / 2 ≤ 1 / (a ^ 3 * (b + c)) + 1 / (b ^ 3 * (a + c)) + 1 / (c ^ 3 * (a + b)) :=

(A) 74

/- 5. Let $x$ and $y$ be distinct positive integers, satisfying $\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y} = \frac{2}{13}$. Then the last two digits of $x^{y}+y^{x}$ are ( ).
(A) 74
(B) 84
(C) 75
(D) 85 -/
theorem algebra_321746 {x y : ℕ} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0) (hxy : x ≠ y)
    (h : (1 / x : ℚ) + (1 / y : ℚ) = 2 / 13) :

soln_description:
15. The result follows from the following lemma by taking $n=\frac{1902 \cdot 1993}{2}$ and $M=\{d, 2 d, \ldots, 1992 d\}$.
Lemma. For every $n \in \mathbb{N}$ there exists a natural number $d$ such that all the numbers $d, 2 d, \ldots, n d$ are of the form $m^{k}(m, k \in \mathbb{N}, k \geq 2)$.
Proof. Let $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n}$ be distinct prime numbers. We shall find $d$ in the form $d=2^{\alpha_{2}} 3^{\alpha_{x}} \cdots n^{\alpha_{n}}$, where $\alpha_{i} \geq 0$ are integers such that $k d$ is a perfect $p_{k}$ th power. It is sufficient to find $\alpha_{i}, i=2,3, \ldots, n$, such that $\alpha_{i} \equiv 0\left(\bmod p_{j}\right)$ if $i \neq j$ and $\alpha_{i} \equiv-1\left(\bmod p_{j}\right)$ if $i=j$. But
the existence of such $\alpha_{i}$ 's is an immediate consequence of the Chinese remainder theorem.
informal_statement:
15. (PRK 2) Does there exist a set $M$ with the following properties?
(i) The set $M$ consists of 1992 natural numbers.
(ii) Every element in $M$ and the sum of any number of elements have the form $m^{k}(m, k \in \mathbb{N}, k \geq 2)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 15. (PRK 2) Does there exist a set $M$ with the following properties?
(i) The set $M$ consists of 1992 natural numbers.
(ii) Every element in $M$ and the sum of any number of elements have the form $m^{k}(m, k \in \mathbb{N}, k \geq 2)$. -/
theorem number_theory_260330 :
    ∃ M : Finset ℕ, M.card = 1992 ∧ ∀ n ∈ M, ∃ m k : ℕ, k ≥ 2 ∧ n = m ^ k ∧
      ∀ S ⊆ M, S.card > 0 → ∃ m k : ℕ, k ≥ 2 ∧ ∑ n ∈ S, n = m ^ k := by

informal_statement: The graph of the function $y=x^2-18x$ intersects the $x$-axis at points $A\left( 0,0 \right)$ and $B\left( 18,0 \right)$. If $C\left( a,b\right)$ is a point on $y=x^2-18x$ and is located in the fourth quadrant, find the maximum area of $\triangle ABC$.
informal_proof:
The area of the triangle $\triangle ABC$ is given by the formula $\frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$. The base is the distance between points $A(0,0)$ and $B(18,0)$, which is $18$. Since the point $C(a,b)$ is in the fourth quadrant, its $y$-coordinate $b$ is negative. The height of the triangle is the perpendicular distance from $C$ to the $x$-axis, which is $|b| = -b$.
Thus, the area of $\triangle ABC$ is $\frac{1}{2} \cdot 18 \cdot (-b) = 9(-b)$.

We want to find the maximum value of this area, which is equivalent to proving the inequality stated in the theorem: $\frac{1}{2} \cdot 18 \cdot (-b) \le 729$.

First, let's simplify this inequality:
$9(-b) \le 729$
Dividing by 9, we get:
$-b \le 81$
Which is equivalent to:
$b \ge -81$

So, our goal is to prove that $b \ge -81$.

We are given that the point $C(a, b)$ lies on the graph of $y = x^2 - 18x$. This gives us the equation:
$b = a^2 - 18a$

We can find the minimum value of this quadratic expression by completing the square for the terms involving $a$:
$b = (a^2 - 18a + 81) - 81$
$b = (a - 9)^2 - 81$

For any real number $a$, the term $(a - 9)^2$ is a square and must be non-negative. That is:
$(a - 9)^2 \ge 0$

Using this fact, we can establish a lower bound for $b$:
$b = (a - 9)^2 - 81 \ge 0 - 81$
$b \ge -81$

This is precisely the inequality we needed to demonstrate. Since we have shown that $b \ge -81$, it follows that the area, $9(-b)$, is at most $9(81) = 729$.

Therefore, $\frac{1}{2} \cdot 18 \cdot (-b) \le 729$.

This maximum area is achieved when $(a - 9)^2 = 0$, i.e., when $a=9$, which gives $b = -81$. This point $C(9, -81)$ lies in the fourth quadrant as required.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The graph of the function $y=x^2-18x$ intersects the $x$-axis at points $A\left( 0,0 \right)$ and $B\left( 18,0 \right)$. If $C\left( a,b\right)$ is a point on $y=x^2-18x$ and is located in the fourth quadrant, find the maximum area of $\triangle ABC$. -/
theorem algebra_12946 (a b : ℝ) (ha : a^2 - 18 * a = b) (hb : b < 0) :
    (1 / 2) * 18 * (-b) ≤ 729 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_12946 (a b : ℝ) (ha : a^2 - 18 * a = b) (hb : b < 0) :
    (1 / 2) * 18 * (-b) ≤ 729 := by 
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - 9)]

informal_statement:
Trouver toutes les fonctions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ telles que

$$
f\left(a^{2}\right)-f\left(b^{2}\right) \leqslant(f(a)+b)(a-f(b)), \quad \text { pour tous } a, b \in \mathbb{R}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Trouver toutes les fonctions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ telles que

$$
f\left(a^{2}\right)-f\left(b^{2}\right) \leqslant(f(a)+b)(a-f(b)), \quad \text { pour tous } a, b \in \mathbb{R}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_605258:
    {f : ℝ → ℝ |
      ∀ a b : ℝ, f (a ^ 2) - f (b ^ 2) ≤ (f a + b) * (a - f b)} = {f | ∀ x, f x = x} ∪ {f | ∀ x, f x = -x}:= by

informal_statement: Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$. Prove that if $\lfloor na \rfloor + \lfloor nb \rfloor = \lfloor nc \rfloor$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$, then $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$. Prove that if $\lfloor na \rfloor + \lfloor nb \rfloor = \lfloor nc \rfloor$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$, then $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$. -/
theorem number_theory_3024
    (a b c : ℝ)
    (h : ∀ n : ℕ, ⌊n * a⌋ + ⌊n * b⌋ = ⌊n * c⌋) :
    (∃ m1 m2 : ℤ, a = m1 ∧ b = m2)
 := by

informal_statement:
Solve the system of simultaneous equations
\[\sqrt x - \frac 1y - 2w + 3z = 1,\]\[x + \frac{1}{y^2} - 4w^2 - 9z^2 = 3,\]\[x \sqrt x - \frac{1}{y^3} - 8w^3 + 27z^3 = -5,\]\[x^2 + \frac{1}{y^4} - 16w^4 - 81z^4 = 15.\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the system of simultaneous equations
\[\sqrt x - \frac 1y - 2w + 3z = 1,\]\[x + \frac{1}{y^2} - 4w^2 - 9z^2 = 3,\]\[x \sqrt x - \frac{1}{y^3} - 8w^3 + 27z^3 = -5,\]\[x^2 + \frac{1}{y^4} - 16w^4 - 81z^4 = 15.\] -/
theorem algebra_25456 {x y w z : ℝ} (h₀ : Real.sqrt x - 1 / y - 2 * w + 3 * z = 1)
    (h₁ : x + 1 / y ^ 2 - 4 * w ^ 2 - 9 * z ^ 2 = 3) (h₂ : x * Real.sqrt x - 1 / y ^ 3 - 8 * w ^ 3 + 27 * z ^ 3 = -5)
    (h₃ : x ^ 2 + 1 / y ^ 4 - 16 * w ^ 4 - 81 * z ^ 4 = 15) :
    (x, y, w, z) = (1, 1 / 2, -1 / 2, 1 / 3) := by

informal_statement: Let $n \geq 3$ be a positive integer. Consider $n$ positive integers $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ that are pairwise coprime, and there exist $k_1, k_2, \ldots, k_n \in \{-1, 1\}$ such that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} k_i a_i = 0$. Determine whether there exist positive integers $b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n$ such that for any positive integer $k$, the numbers $b_1 + k a_1, b_2 + k a_2, \ldots, b_n + k a_n$ are pairwise coprime.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $n \geq 3$ be a positive integer. Consider $n$ positive integers $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ that are pairwise coprime, and there exist $k_1, k_2, \ldots, k_n \in \{-1, 1\}$ such that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} k_i a_i = 0$. Determine whether there exist positive integers $b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n$ such that for any positive integer $k$, the numbers $b_1 + k a_1, b_2 + k a_2, \ldots, b_n + k a_n$ are pairwise coprime. -/
theorem number_theory_6361 (n : ℕ) (hn : 3 ≤ n) (a : Fin n → ℤ)
    (apos : ∀ i, 0 < a i) (acoprime : ∀ i j, i ≠ j → IsCoprime (a i) (a j))
    (k : Fin n → ℤ) (k1 : ∀ i, k i = -1 ∨ k i = 1)
    (hsum : ∑ i, k i * a i = 0) :
    ∃ b : Fin n → ℤ, (∀ i, 0 < b i) ∧
      (∀ k' : ℤ, 0 < k' → ∀ i j, i ≠ j → IsCoprime (b i + k' * a i) (b j + k' * a j)) := by

soln_description: 3.19. Consider the polynomial $P(t)=t^{3}+t^{2} z+t y+x$. The pairwise distinct numbers $a, b, c$ are roots of the polynomial $P(t)$. Therefore, $P(t)=(t-a)(t-b)(t-c)$, which means $x=-a b c, y=a b+b c+c a$, $z=-(a+b+c)$.
informal_statement:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x + a y + a^{2} z + a^{3} = 0 \\
x + b y + b^{2} z + b^{3} = 0 \\
x + c y + c^{2} z + c^{3} = 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

34
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3.19. Let $a, b, c$ be pairwise distinct numbers. Solve the system of equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x + a y + a^{2} z + a^{3} = 0 \\
x + b y + b^{2} z + b^{3} = 0 \\
x + c y + c^{2} z + c^{3} = 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

34 -/
theorem algebra_223121 {a b c x y z : ℝ} (ha : a ≠ b) (hb : b ≠ c) (hc : a ≠ c)
    (h1 : x + a * y + a ^ 2 * z + a ^ 3 = 0) (h2 : x + b * y + b ^ 2 * z + b ^ 3 = 0)
    (h3 : x + c * y + c ^ 2 * z + c ^ 3 = 0) :
    x = -a * b * c ∧ y = -a - b - c ∧ z = 1 := by

soln_description:
9.5 We have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{a_{1}}{a_{2}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)}+\frac{a_{2}}{a_{3}\left(a_{2}+a_{3}\right)}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{a_{1}\left(a_{n}+a_{1}\right)} \\
=\left(\frac{1}{a_{2}}-\frac{1}{a_{1}+a_{2}}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{a_{3}}-\frac{1}{a_{2}+a_{3}}\right)+\cdots \\
+\left(\frac{1}{a_{1}}-\frac{1}{a_{n}+a_{1}}\right) \\
=\left(\frac{1}{a_{1}}-\frac{1}{a_{1}+a_{2}}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{a_{2}}-\frac{1}{a_{2}+a_{3}}\right)+\cdots \\
+\left(\frac{1}{a_{n}}-\frac{1}{a_{n}+a_{1}}\right) \\
=\frac{a_{2}}{a_{1}\left(a_{1}+a_{8}\right)}+\frac{a_{3}}{a_{2}\left(a_{2}+a_{3}\right)}+\cdots+\frac{a_{1}}{a_{n}\left(a_{n}+a_{1}\right)} . \\
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
9.5 Prove the identity
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{a_{1}}{a_{2}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)}+\frac{a_{2}}{a_{3}\left(a_{2}+a_{3}\right)}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{a_{1}\left(a_{n}+a_{1}\right)} \\
=\frac{a_{2}}{a_{1}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)}+\frac{a_{3}}{a_{2}\left(a_{2}+a_{3}\right)}+\cdots+\frac{a_{1}}{a_{n}\left(a_{n}+a_{1}\right)} .

$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- 9.5 Prove the identity
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{a_{1}}{a_{2}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)}+\frac{a_{2}}{a_{3}\left(a_{2}+a_{3}\right)}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{a_{1}\left(a_{n}+a_{1}\right)} \\
=\frac{a_{2}}{a_{1}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)}+\frac{a_{3}}{a_{2}\left(a_{2}+a_{3}\right)}+\cdots+\frac{a_{1}}{a_{n}\left(a_{n}+a_{1}\right)} .
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_307439 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (a : ℕ → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i ∈ range n, 0 < a i) :
    ∑ i ∈ range n, a i / (a ((i + 1) % n) * (a i + a ((i + 1) % n))) =
    ∑ i ∈ range n, a ((i + 1) % n) / (a i * (a ((i + 1) % n) + a i)) := by

soln_description:
1. **Express the sum \( x \) in a different form:**

   Given the sum:
   \[
   x = \sum_{k \ge 0} \binom{n}{2k} 2^{n-2k} 3^k
   \]
   We can rewrite this sum using the binomial theorem and properties of binomial coefficients. Notice that:
   \[
   x = \frac{1}{2} \left( \sum_{i=0}^n \binom{n}{i} 2^i (\sqrt{3})^{n-i} + \sum_{i=0}^n \binom{n}{i} 2^i (-\sqrt{3})^{n-i} \right)
   \]
   This is because the terms where \( i \) is odd cancel out due to the symmetry of the binomial coefficients and the alternating sign of \( (-\sqrt{3})^{n-i} \).

2. **Simplify the expression:**

   Using the binomial theorem, we can simplify the sums:
   \[
   x = \frac{1}{2} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^n + (2 - \sqrt{3})^n \right)
   \]
   This expression shows that \( x \) is a combination of terms involving \( (2 + \sqrt{3})^n \) and \( (2 - \sqrt{3})^n \).

3. **Relate \( x \) to the Pell's equation:**

   The expression \( x = \frac{1}{2} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^n + (2 - \sqrt{3})^n \right) \) suggests that \( x \) is a solution to the Pell's equation \( x^2 - 3y^2 = 1 \). This is because the fundamental solution to this Pell's equation is \( (2, 1) \), and higher solutions can be generated by powers of \( (2 + \sqrt{3}) \) and \( (2 - \sqrt{3}) \).

4. **Verify the triangle sides:**

   We need to show that \( 2x-1, 2x, 2x+1 \) form the sides of a triangle. For three lengths to form a triangle, the sum of any two sides must be greater than the third side. We check:
   \[
   (2x-1) + 2x > 2x+1 \implies 4x-1 > 2x+1 \implies 2x > 2 \implies x > 1
   \]
   \[
   (2x-1) + (2x+1) > 2x \implies 4x > 2x \implies 2x > 0 \implies x > 0
   \]
   \[
   2x + (2x+1) > 2x-1 \implies 4x+1 > 2x-1 \implies 2x > -2 \implies x > -1
   \]
   Since \( x \ge 1 \), all these inequalities are satisfied.

5. **Calculate the area and inradius:**

   Using Heron's formula, the area \( A \) of the triangle with sides \( a = 2x-1 \), \( b = 2x \), and \( c = 2x+1 \) is:
   \[
   s = \frac{(2x-1) + 2x + (2x+1)}{2} = 3x
   \]
   \[
   A = \sqrt{s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)} = \sqrt{3x(3x - (2x-1))(3x - 2x)(3x - (2x+1))}
   \]
   \[
   A = \sqrt{3x(3x - 2x + 1)(3x - 2x)(3x - 2x - 1)} = \sqrt{3x(x+1)x(x-1)} = \sqrt{3x^2(x^2-1)}
   \]
   Since \( x \) is a solution to the Pell's equation \( x^2 - 3y^2 = 1 \), we have:
   \[
   x^2 - 1 = 3y^2 \implies \frac{x^2 - 1}{3} = y^2
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   A = \sqrt{3x^2 \cdot \frac{x^2 - 1}{3}} = \sqrt{x^2(x^2 - 1)} = x \sqrt{x^2 - 1}
   \]
   The inradius \( r \) is given by:
   \[
   r = \frac{A}{s} = \frac{x \sqrt{x^2 - 1}}{3x} = \frac{\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}{3}
   \]
   Since \( x \) and \( y \) are integers, \( \sqrt{x^2 - 1} = \sqrt{3y^2} = y\sqrt{3} \), which implies \( y \) must be an integer.
informal_statement:
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer and consider the sum $$x=\sum_{k\ge 0} \dbinom{n}{2k} 2^{n-2k}3^k=\dbinom{n}{0}2^n+\dbinom{n}{2}2^{n-2}\cdot{}3+\dbinom{n}{4}2^{n-k}\cdot{}3^2 + \cdots{}.$$
Show that $2x-1,2x,2x+1$ form the sides of a triangle whose area and inradius are also integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer and consider the sum $$x=\sum_{k\ge 0} \dbinom{n}{2k} 2^{n-2k}3^k=\dbinom{n}{0}2^n+\dbinom{n}{2}2^{n-2}\cdot{}3+\dbinom{n}{4}2^{n-k}\cdot{}3^2 + \cdots{}.$$
Show that $2x-1,2x,2x+1$ form the sides of a triangle whose area and inradius are also integers.
 -/
theorem number_theory_61180 {n : ℕ} (hn : 1 ≤ n) :
    ∃ x : ℤ, x = ∑ k in Finset.Icc 0 (n / 2), Nat.choose n (2 * k) * 2^(n - 2 * k) * 3^k ∧
    ∃ a b c : ℤ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ c > 0 ∧ a + b > c ∧ a + c > b ∧ b + c > a ∧
      (a = 2 * x - 1 ∧ b = 2 * x ∧ c = 2 * x + 1) ∧
      ∃ m : ℤ, m = (1 / 2) * a * b * sin (arccos ((a^2 + b^2 - c^2) / (2 * a * b))) ∧
      ∃ r : ℤ, r > 0 ∧ m = r * (a + b + c) / 2 := by

soln_description:
Let $N=p_{1}^{k_{1}} \ldots p_{s}^{k_{s}}$, be the prime factorization of $N$. Without loss of generality, we can assume that $P=p_{1}$. Then

$d(N)=\left(k_{1}+1\right)\left(k_{2}+1\right) \ldots\left(k_{\mathrm{s}}+1\right)$ and $\frac{N}{d(N)}=\frac{p_{1}^{k_{1}}}{k_{1}+1} \cdot \ldots \cdot \frac{p_{s}^{k_{s}}}{k_{s}+1}=p_{1}$. It is not difficult to verify that if $p>3, k \geq 2$, then $\frac{p^{k}}{k+1}>p$, and if $p=3, k=2$, then $\frac{p^{k}}{k+1}=p$;

if $p=3, k>2$, then $\frac{p^{k}}{k+1}>p$;

if $p \geq 2$, then $\frac{p^{k}}{k+1} \geq 1$, and if $p>2$ or $k>1$, the inequality is strict;

if $p=2, k \geq 4$, then $\frac{p^{k}}{k+1}>p$.

Consider two cases:

1) $N$ is divisible by $p_{1}^{2}$, that is, $k_{1} \geq 2$. By the inequalities given, $\frac{p_{1}^{k_{1}}}{k_{1}+1} \cdot \ldots \cdot \frac{p_{s}^{k_{s}}}{k_{s}+1}$ is not greater than $p_{1}$ only when $p_{1}=3, k_{1}=2$ or $p_{1}=2, k_{1}=2$ or 3.

In the first case, the product already has a factor equal to $p_{1}$, so all other factors must be equal to one. Therefore, either $N=9$ or $N=2 \cdot 9=18$.

In the second case, if $k_{1}=3$, then $\frac{p_{1}^{k_{1}}}{k_{1}+1}=2$, and thus $N=8$. If $k_{1}=2$, then $\frac{p_{1}^{k_{1}}}{k_{1}+1}=4 / 3$. A three appears in the denominator, so $N$ must be divisible by 3. The number $N=3 \cdot 2^{2}$ works, and since $\frac{3^{k}}{k+1}>1.5$ for $k>1$, the number 3 cannot appear in a higher power in the factorization of $N$.

Thus, in this case, the numbers $N=8,9,12$ and 18 work.
2) $k_{1}=1$. Then the first factor is $p_{1 / 2}$. Therefore, the product of the remaining factors is 2. If the number $N$ has a prime divisor not less than 5, then the corresponding factor is greater than 2, which is impossible. Therefore, $N=p \cdot 2^{5^{3 r}}$ and $r \leq 1$ (otherwise $\frac{3^{r}}{r+1}>2$) and $s \leq 3$ (otherwise $\frac{2^{t}}{s+1}>2$). By checking all these cases, we find that the numbers $N=24,8 p, 12 p, 18 p$ work.

## Answer

$8,9,12,18,24,8 p, 12 p, 18 p$, where $p$ is any prime number greater than 3.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Induction (other).

]

Let $d(N)$ denote the number of divisors of $N$ (the numbers 1 and $N$ are also considered divisors). Find all such $N$ for which the number $P=\frac{N}{d(N)}$ is prime. -/
theorem number_theory_175415 {N : ℕ} (hN : N ≠ 0) :
    Nat.Prime (N / (Nat.divisors N).card) ↔
    N = 8 ∨ N = 9 ∨ N = 12 ∨ N = 18 ∨ N = 24 ∨
      ∃ p, N = p * 8 ∨ N = p * 12 ∨ N = p * 18 := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $y=\omega x, \omega \neq 1$, substituting into the given condition yields $1+\omega+\omega^{2}=0$. Therefore, $(1-\omega)\left(1+\omega+\omega^{2}\right)=0$, which implies $\omega^{3}=1$.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad \text { the original expression } & =\frac{1}{(1+\omega)^{1990}}+\frac{\omega^{1990}}{(1+\omega)^{1990}}=\frac{1+\omega^{1990}}{\left(-\omega^{2}\right)^{1990}} \\
& =\frac{1+\omega^{3 \times 663+1}}{\omega^{2 \times(3 \times 663+1)}}=\frac{1+\omega}{\omega^{2}}=-1 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the answer is $(B)$.
informal_statement:

(A) $2^{-1989}$.
(B) -1 .
(C) 1 .
(D) None of the above answers is correct.

import Mathlib

/- $12 \cdot 6$ Let non-zero complex numbers $x, y$ satisfy $x^{2}+x y+y^{2}=0$, then the value of the algebraic expression $\left(\frac{x}{x+y}\right)^{1990}+\left(\frac{y}{x+y}\right)^{1990}$ is
(A) $2^{-1989}$.
(B) -1 .
(C) 1 .
(D) None of the above answers is correct.
(China High School Mathematics League, 1990) -/
theorem algebra_161166 {x y : ℂ} (hx : x ≠ 0) (hy : y ≠ 0) (h : x^2 + x * y + y^2 = 0) :
    ((x / (x + y)) ^ 1990 + (y / (x + y)) ^ 1990) = -1 := by

soln_description: 16) The answer is (B). (i) is false, for example, 25 and 27 are two consecutive odd numbers, both of which are not prime. (ii) is false, for example, 23, 25, and 27 are three consecutive odd numbers, two of which are not prime. (iii) is true because given four consecutive odd numbers (in fact, three would suffice), at least one is divisible by 3 and therefore not prime (the case $1,3,5,7$ has 1 which is not prime). (iv) is false, for example, $11,13,15,17,19$ are five consecutive odd numbers, of which only one is not prime.
informal_statement:
16) How many of the following statements about natural numbers are true?

(i) Given any two consecutive odd numbers, at least one is prime.

(ii) Given any three consecutive odd numbers, at least two are prime.

(iii) Given any four consecutive odd numbers, at least one is not prime.

(iv) Given any five consecutive odd numbers, at least two are not prime.
(A) None
(B) one
(C) two
(D) three
(E) four.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 16) How many of the following statements about natural numbers are true?

(i) Given any two consecutive odd numbers, at least one is prime.

(ii) Given any three consecutive odd numbers, at least two are prime.

(iii) Given any four consecutive odd numbers, at least one is not prime.

(iv) Given any five consecutive odd numbers, at least two are not prime.
(A) None
(B) one
(C) two
(D) three
(E) four. -/
theorem number_theory_128362 :
    (∀ n : ℕ, Odd n → Prime n ∨ Prime (n + 2)) ∧
    ¬(∀ n : ℕ, Odd n → Odd (n + 2) → Prime n ∧ Prime (n + 2)) ∧
    ¬(∀ n : ℕ, Odd n → Odd (n + 2) → Odd (n + 4) → Prime n ∧ Prime (n + 2) ∧ Prime (n + 4)) ∧
    (∀ n : ℕ, Odd n → Odd (n + 2) → Odd (n + 4) → Odd (n + 6) → Prime n ∧ Prime (n + 2) ∧ Prime (n + 4) ∧ Prime (n + 6)) := by

soln_description:
}

The two numbers to be multiplied can be written in the form \(10+a\) and \(10+b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are their units digits. According to the described method, one first forms \(10+a+b\), then \(10 \cdot(10+a+b)\), and finally \(10 \cdot(10+a+b)+a \cdot b\). This number is equal to

\[
100+10 a+10 b+a b
\]

On the other hand, the desired product is

\[
(10+a) \cdot(10+b)=100+10 a+10 b+a b
\]

It therefore agrees with the number calculated according to the method. w.z.b.w.
informal_statement:
\section*{Problem 1 - 241011}

Two natural numbers, which lie between 10 and 20, can be multiplied relatively quickly and safely in your head according to the following method:

Add to the first number the unit digit of the second number, append a 0 to the resulting sum, and add to the now obtained number the product of the unit digits of the two given numbers.

To calculate \(16 \cdot 12\) according to this rule, for example, add 2 to 16, resulting in 18, append a 0 to get 180, and add to this number the product \(6 \cdot 2\), which is 12. This results in 192, indeed the desired number \(16 \cdot 12\).

Prove that this method yields the correct result for all natural numbers between 10 and 20!
informal_proof:
Let `x` and `y` be natural numbers. We are given the conditions `10 ≤ x < 20` and `10 ≤ y < 20`. This means that `x` must be an integer in the set `{10, 11, ..., 19}` and `y` must also be an integer in the set `{10, 11, ..., 19}`.

The proof proceeds by an exhaustive case analysis of all possible integer values for `x` and `y`. We will verify the equality
`(x + (y % 10)) * 10 + (x % 10) * (y % 10) = x * y`
for each of the `10 * 10 = 100` possible pairs of `(x, y)`.

Let's illustrate the process with the example given in the problem description, where `x = 16` and `y = 12`. These values satisfy the given conditions.
- The unit digit of `x` is `16 % 10 = 6`.
- The unit digit of `y` is `12 % 10 = 2`.

Substituting these values into the left-hand side of the equation, we get:
`(16 + 2) * 10 + 6 * 2`
`= 18 * 10 + 12`
`= 180 + 12`
`= 192`

The right-hand side of the equation is the product `x * y`:
`16 * 12 = 192`

Since `192 = 192`, the equality holds for the case where `x = 16` and `y = 12`.

By systematically checking all 100 pairs of values for `x` and `y` from the set `{10, 11, ..., 19}`, we find that the equality holds true in every single case. Since we have exhausted all possibilities allowed by the hypotheses, we conclude that the statement is true for all `x` and `y` in the specified range.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- \section*{Problem 1 - 241011}

Two natural numbers, which lie between 10 and 20, can be multiplied relatively quickly and safely in your head according to the following method:

Add to the first number the unit digit of the second number, append a 0 to the resulting sum, and add to the now obtained number the product of the unit digits of the two given numbers.

To calculate \(16 \cdot 12\) according to this rule, for example, add 2 to 16, resulting in 18, append a 0 to get 180, and add to this number the product \(6 \cdot 2\), which is 12. This results in 192, indeed the desired number \(16 \cdot 12\).

Prove that this method yields the correct result for all natural numbers between 10 and 20! -/
theorem algebra_189485 (x y : ℕ) (hx : 10 ≤ x) (hy : 10 ≤ y)
    (hxy : x < 20 ∧ y < 20) :
    (x + (y % 10)) * 10 + (x % 10) * (y % 10) = x * y := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_189485 (x y : ℕ) (hx : 10 ≤ x) (hy : 10 ≤ y)
    (hxy : x < 20 ∧ y < 20) :
    (x + (y % 10)) * 10 + (x % 10) * (y % 10) = x * y := by 
  rcases hxy with ⟨hx2, hy2⟩
  interval_cases x <;> interval_cases y 
    <;> norm_num
  all_goals omega

soln_description:
For any $k(1 \leqslant k \leqslant n)$, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(k a_{k}\right)^{2} \leqslant\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} i a_{i}\right)^{2}=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} i b_{i}\right)^{2} \\
\leqslant\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} i^{2} b_{i}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right) \leqslant\left(10-k^{2} a_{k}\right)\left(1-a_{k}\right) \\
=10-\left(10+k^{2}\right) a_{k}+k^{2} a_{k}^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $a_{k} \leqslant \frac{10}{10+k^{2}}$.
Similarly, $b_{k} \leqslant \frac{10}{10+k^{2}}$.
Therefore, $\max \left\{a_{k}, b_{k}\right\} \leqslant \frac{10}{10+k^{2}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Let non-negative real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{n}$ satisfy the following conditions:
(1) $\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)=1$;
(2) $\sum_{i=1}^{n} i\left(a_{i}-b_{i}\right)=0$;
(3) $\sum_{i=1}^{n} i^{2}\left(a_{i}+b_{i}\right)=10$.
Prove that for any $k(1 \leqslant k \leqslant n)$, $\max \left\{a_{k}, b_{k}\right\} \leqslant \frac{10}{10+k^{2}}$. (Li Shenghong) -/
theorem algebra_304089 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (a b : Fin n → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i, 0 ≤ a i) (hb : ∀ i, 0 ≤ b i)
    (h1 : ∑ i, (a i + b i) = 1)
    (h2 : ∑ i, (i + 1) * (a i - b i) = 0)
    (h3 : ∑ i, (i + 1)^2 * (a i + b i) = 10) :
    ∀ k, max (a k) (b k) ≤ 10 / (10 + (k + 1)^2) := by

soln_description:
To prove that each \( x_n \) is equal to the sum of squares of two consecutive integers, we start by expressing \( x_n \) in a form that can be analyzed.

1. **Express \( x_n \) in terms of its components:**
   \[
   x_n = \frac{1}{4} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} + (2 - \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} \right)
   \]

2. **Assume \( x_n \) can be written as the sum of squares of two consecutive integers:**
   \[
   x_n = y_n^2 + (y_n + 1)^2
   \]
   Simplify the right-hand side:
   \[
   y_n^2 + (y_n + 1)^2 = y_n^2 + y_n^2 + 2y_n + 1 = 2y_n^2 + 2y_n + 1
   \]
   Therefore, we need to show:
   \[
   x_n = 2y_n^2 + 2y_n + 1
   \]

3. **Relate \( x_n \) to \( y_n \):**
   We need to find \( y_n \) such that:
   \[
   2y_n^2 + 2y_n + 1 = \frac{1}{4} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} + (2 - \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} \right)
   \]

4. **Introduce a new variable \( z_n \) to simplify the expression:**
   Let:
   \[
   z_n = 2y_n + 1
   \]
   Then:
   \[
   2y_n^2 + 2y_n + 1 = \frac{z_n^2 + 1}{2}
   \]
   We need:
   \[
   \frac{z_n^2 + 1}{2} = \frac{1}{4} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} + (2 - \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} \right)
   \]
   Multiply both sides by 2:
   \[
   z_n^2 + 1 = \frac{1}{2} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} + (2 - \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} \right)
   \]

5. **Solve for \( z_n \):**
   \[
   z_n^2 = \frac{1}{2} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} + (2 - \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} \right) - 1
   \]
   \[
   z_n = \sqrt{\frac{1}{2} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} + (2 - \sqrt{3})^{2n-1} \right) - 1}
   \]

6. **Verify the solution:**
   We need to check if:
   \[
   z_n = \frac{1 + \sqrt{3}}{2} \left( (2 + \sqrt{3})^{n-1} + (2 - \sqrt{3})^{n-1} \right)
   \]
   satisfies the equation. This can be verified by substituting back into the original expression and checking if both sides are equal.

The final answer is \( \boxed{ x_n = y_n^2 + (y_n + 1)^2 } \).
informal_statement:
The sequence $\{x_n\}$ is given by
$$x_n=\frac14\left(\left(2+\sqrt3\right)^{2n-1}+\left(2-\sqrt3\right)^{2n-1}\right),\qquad n\in\mathbb N.$$Prove that each $x_n$ is equal to the sum of squares of two consecutive integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The sequence $\{x_n\}$ is given by
$$x_n=\frac14\left(\left(2+\sqrt3\right)^{2n-1}+\left(2-\sqrt3\right)^{2n-1}\right),\qquad n\in\mathbb N.$$Prove that each $x_n$ is equal to the sum of squares of two consecutive integers. -/
theorem algebra_70484 {x : ℕ → ℝ}
    (hx : ∀ n, x n = ((2 + Real.sqrt 3) ^ (2 * n - 1) + (2 - Real.sqrt 3) ^ (2 * n - 1)) / 4) :
    ∀ n, ∃ k, x n = k ^ 2 + (k + 1) ^ 2 := by

soln_description: Prove that by Euler's criterion, -1 is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ if and only if $(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$. Since $p$ is an odd prime, this implies the necessary and sufficient condition is $\frac{p-1}{2} \equiv 0(\bmod 2)$, which is equivalent to $p \equiv 1(\bmod 4)$. The proposition is thus proved.
informal_statement: Example 1 Let $p$ be an odd prime, prove: -1 is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ if and only if $p \equiv 1(\bmod 4)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1 Let $p$ be an odd prime, prove: -1 is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ if and only if $p \equiv 1(\bmod 4)$. -/
theorem number_theory_221757 (p : ℕ) (hp : Odd p ∧ Nat.Prime p) :
    ∃ x, (-1 : ZMod p) = x^2 ↔ p ≡ 1 [MOD 4] := by

soln_description:
3. 0 .

Squaring and adding the two known equations, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
4+2 \sqrt{3}(\sin \alpha \cdot \sin \beta+\cos \alpha \cdot \cos \beta)=4 \\
\Rightarrow \cos (\alpha-\beta)=0
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
3. Given
$$
\sin \alpha+\sqrt{3} \sin \beta=1, \cos \alpha+\sqrt{3} \cos \beta=\sqrt{3} \text {. }
$$

Then the value of $\cos (\alpha-\beta)$ is $\qquad$ .
informal_proof:
We are given the two equations:
1.  $\sin \alpha + \sqrt{3} \sin \beta = 1$
2.  $\cos \alpha + \sqrt{3} \cos \beta = \sqrt{3}$

Our goal is to find the value of $\cos(\alpha - \beta)$.

We begin by squaring both equations.
Squaring the first equation gives:
$$ (\sin \alpha + \sqrt{3} \sin \beta)^2 = 1^2 $$
$$ \sin^2 \alpha + 2\sqrt{3} \sin \alpha \sin \beta + 3 \sin^2 \beta = 1 $$

Squaring the second equation gives:
$$ (\cos \alpha + \sqrt{3} \cos \beta)^2 = (\sqrt{3})^2 $$
$$ \cos^2 \alpha + 2\sqrt{3} \cos \alpha \cos \beta + 3 \cos^2 \beta = 3 $$

Next, we add these two new equations together. The sum of the left-hand sides is:
$$ (\sin^2 \alpha + 2\sqrt{3} \sin \alpha \sin \beta + 3 \sin^2 \beta) + (\cos^2 \alpha + 2\sqrt{3} \cos \alpha \cos \beta + 3 \cos^2 \beta) $$
And the sum of the right-hand sides is $1 + 3 = 4$.

Let's rearrange and group the terms on the left-hand side:
$$ (\sin^2 \alpha + \cos^2 \alpha) + 3(\sin^2 \beta + \cos^2 \beta) + 2\sqrt{3}(\sin \alpha \sin \beta + \cos \alpha \cos \beta) = 4 $$

We use the fundamental Pythagorean identity, $\sin^2\theta + \cos^2\theta = 1$. Applying this for both $\alpha$ and $\beta$, we can simplify the expression:
$$ (1) + 3(1) + 2\sqrt{3}(\sin \alpha \sin \beta + \cos \alpha \cos \beta) = 4 $$
$$ 4 + 2\sqrt{3}(\sin \alpha \sin \beta + \cos \alpha \cos \beta) = 4 $$

Subtracting 4 from both sides yields:
$$ 2\sqrt{3}(\sin \alpha \sin \beta + \cos \alpha \cos \beta) = 0 $$

Since $2\sqrt{3}$ is not zero, we can divide both sides by it to get:
$$ \sin \alpha \sin \beta + \cos \alpha \cos \beta = 0 $$

Finally, we recall the angle subtraction formula for cosine:
$$ \cos(\alpha - \beta) = \cos \alpha \cos \beta + \sin \alpha \sin \beta $$

Substituting our result into this formula, we find:
$$ \cos(\alpha - \beta) = 0 $$
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Given
$$
\sin \alpha+\sqrt{3} \sin \beta=1, \cos \alpha+\sqrt{3} \cos \beta=\sqrt{3} \text {. }
$$

Then the value of $\cos (\alpha-\beta)$ is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_310086 (α β : ℝ) (h₁ : Real.sin α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.sin β = 1) (h₂ : Real.cos α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.cos β = Real.sqrt 3) :
    Real.cos (α - β) = 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_310086 (α β : ℝ) (h₁ : Real.sin α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.sin β = 1) (h₂ : Real.cos α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.cos β = Real.sqrt 3) :
    Real.cos (α - β) = 0 := by
  have h3 : Real.sin α ^ 2 + Real.cos α ^ 2 = 1 := Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq α
  have h4 : Real.sin β ^ 2 + Real.cos β ^ 2 = 1 := Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq β

  have eq1 : (Real.sin α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.sin β) ^ 2 = 1 := by
    rw [h₁]
    all_goals norm_num

  have eq2 : (Real.cos α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.cos β) ^ 2 = 3 := by
    rw [h₂]
    all_goals norm_num

  have eq3 : (Real.sin α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.sin β) ^ 2 + (Real.cos α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.cos β) ^ 2 = 4 := by
    linarith [eq1, eq2]

  have eq4 : (Real.sin α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.sin β) ^ 2 + (Real.cos α + Real.sqrt 3 * Real.cos β) ^ 2 =
      (Real.sin α ^ 2 + Real.cos α ^ 2) + 3 * (Real.sin β ^ 2 + Real.cos β ^ 2) + 2 * Real.sqrt 3 * (Real.sin α * Real.sin β + Real.cos α * Real.cos β) := by
    ring_nf
    <;> simp [mul_pow, Real.sqrt_sq]
    <;> ring

  rw [eq4] at eq3
  rw [h3, h4] at eq3

  have eq5 : 2 * Real.sqrt 3 * (Real.sin α * Real.sin β + Real.cos α * Real.cos β) = 0 := by
    nlinarith

  have eq6 : Real.sin α * Real.sin β + Real.cos α * Real.cos β = 0 := by
    have h7 : Real.sqrt 3 > 0 := Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (by norm_num : (3 : ℝ) > 0)
    nlinarith

  have h : Real.cos (α - β) = Real.cos α * Real.cos β + Real.sin α * Real.sin β := Real.cos_sub α β
  rw [h]
  linarith [eq6]

soln_description: $\begin{array}{l}\text { Analysis: }(50 \div 20) \times 100+(50 \div 25) \times 100+(50 \div 5) \times 100+(50 \div 10) \times 100 \\ =250+200+1000+500 \\ =1950\end{array}$
informal_statement: 10. The graph on the right shows the fuel consumption per 100 kilometers for four different types of cars: $U, V, W, X$. If each car has 50 liters of fuel, what is the maximum total distance that these four cars can travel in kilometers?
informal_proof:
Let `u`, `v`, `w`, and `x` be real numbers defined as follows:
- `u = 50 / 100`
- `v = 60 / 100`
- `w = 70 / 100`
- `x = 80 / 100`

We want to prove the inequality:
`50 / u + 50 / v + 50 / w + 50 / x ≤ 1950`

First, we substitute the given values of `u`, `v`, `w`, and `x` into the left-hand side of the inequality. The expression becomes:
`50 / (50 / 100) + 50 / (60 / 100) + 50 / (70 / 100) + 50 / (80 / 100)`

By simplifying each term, we get:
` (50 * 100) / 50 + (50 * 100) / 60 + (50 * 100) / 70 + (50 * 100) / 80 `
` = 100 + 5000 / 60 + 5000 / 70 + 5000 / 80 `
` = 100 + 250 / 3 + 500 / 7 + 125 / 2 `

To evaluate this sum, we find a common denominator, which is 42:
` = 4200 / 42 + 3500 / 42 + 3000 / 42 + 2625 / 42 `
` = (4200 + 3500 + 3000 + 2625) / 42 `
` = 13325 / 42 `

The value of this expression is approximately 317.26. Since `13325 / 42` is clearly less than or equal to `1950`, the inequality holds.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. The graph on the right shows the fuel consumption per 100 kilometers for four different types of cars: $U, V, W, X$. If each car has 50 liters of fuel, what is the maximum total distance that these four cars can travel in kilometers? -/
theorem other_162431 (u v w x : ℝ)
    (h₀ : u = 50 / 100) (h₁ : v = 60 / 100) (h₂ : w = 70 / 100) (h₃ : x = 80 / 100)
    (h₄ : 0 < u ∧ u < 1) (h₅ : 0 < v ∧ v < 1) (h₆ : 0 < w ∧ w < 1) (h₇ : 0 < x ∧ x < 1) :
    50 / u + 50 / v + 50 / w + 50 / x ≤ 1950 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem other_162431 (u v w x : ℝ)
    (h₀ : u = 50 / 100) (h₁ : v = 60 / 100) (h₂ : w = 70 / 100) (h₃ : x = 80 / 100)
    (h₄ : 0 < u ∧ u < 1) (h₅ : 0 < v ∧ v < 1) (h₆ : 0 < w ∧ w < 1) (h₇ : 0 < x ∧ x < 1) :
    50 / u + 50 / v + 50 / w + 50 / x ≤ 1950 := by 
        rw [h₀, h₁, h₂, h₃]
        norm_num

soln_description:
To show that any such sequence of primes has a finite number of terms, we need to consider the two possible cases for the sequence: when all signs are \(+\) and when all signs are \(-\).

1. **Case 1: All signs are \(+\)**

   The sequence is given by:
   \[
   p, 2p+1, 4p+3, \ldots, 2^k(p+1)-1, \ldots
   \]
   We need to show that this sequence cannot be infinite. Consider the fifth term of the sequence:
   \[
   2^4(p+1) - 1 = 16(p+1) - 1 = 16p + 15
   \]
   If \(5 \nmid (p+1)\), then \(16p + 15\) is divisible by 5. This is because:
   \[
   16p + 15 \equiv 16(p+1) - 1 \equiv 16(p+1) - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{5}
   \]
   Therefore, \(16p + 15\) is not a prime number if \(5 \nmid (p+1)\).

2. **Case 2: All signs are \(-\)**

   The sequence is given by:
   \[
   p, 2p-1, 4p-3, \ldots, 2^k(p-1)+1, \ldots
   \]
   We need to show that this sequence cannot be infinite. Consider the fifth term of the sequence:
   \[
   2^4(p-1) + 1 = 16(p-1) + 1 = 16p - 15
   \]
   If \(5 \nmid (p-1)\), then \(16p - 15\) is divisible by 5. This is because:
   \[
   16p - 15 \equiv 16(p-1) + 1 \equiv 16(p-1) + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{5}
   \]
   Therefore, \(16p - 15\) is not a prime number if \(5 \nmid (p-1)\).

3. **General Case: Mixed signs**

   For a general sequence where the signs can be mixed, we need to consider the properties of the sequence modulo some prime \(q\). Let \(q\) be a prime such that there exists an integer \(m\) with:
   \[
   q \mid 2^m - (p+1) \quad \text{or} \quad q \mid 2^m + (p-1)
   \]
   Then for all \(k = r(q-1) - m\), we have:
   \[
   q \mid 2^k(p+1) - 1 \quad \text{or} \quad q \mid 2^k(p-1) + 1
   \]
   This implies that the sequence will eventually contain a term that is divisible by \(q\), and hence not a prime.

Therefore, in all cases, the sequence cannot be infinite because it will eventually contain a term that is not a prime number.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Consider the sequence $p_{1},p_{2},...$ of primes such that for each $i\geq2$, either $p_{i}=2p_{i-1}-1$ or $p_{i}=2p_{i-1}+1$. Show that any such sequence has a finite number of terms.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Consider the sequence $p_{1},p_{2},...$ of primes such that for each $i\geq2$, either $p_{i}=2p_{i-1}-1$ or $p_{i}=2p_{i-1}+1$. Show that any such sequence has a finite number of terms. -/
theorem number_theory_72463 (p : ℕ+ → ℕ+) (hp : ∀ i, Nat.Prime (p i))
  (hpi : ∀ i ≥ 2, p i = 2 * p (i - 1) - 1 ∨ p i = 2 * p (i - 1) + 1) :
  (Set.range p).Finite := by

informal_statement:
For three distinct real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}$, define three real numbers $b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}$ as follows:
$b_{j}=\left(1+\frac{a_{j} a_{i}}{a_{j}-a_{i}}\right)\left(1+\frac{a_{j} a_{k}}{a_{j}-a_{k}}\right)$, where $\{i, j, k\}=\{1,2,3\}$.
Prove: $1+\left|a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+a_{3} b_{3}\right| \leqslant\left(1+\left|a_{1}\right|\right)\left(1+\left|a_{2}\right|\right)\left(1+\left|a_{3}\right|\right)$. Also, determine the conditions under which equality holds. (2006 China Mathematical Olympiad Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- For three distinct real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}$, define three real numbers $b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}$ as follows:
$b_{j}=\left(1+\frac{a_{j} a_{i}}{a_{j}-a_{i}}\right)\left(1+\frac{a_{j} a_{k}}{a_{j}-a_{k}}\right)$, where $\{i, j, k\}=\{1,2,3\}$.
Prove: $1+\left|a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+a_{3} b_{3}\right| \leqslant\left(1+\left|a_{1}\right|\right)\left(1+\left|a_{2}\right|\right)\left(1+\left|a_{3}\right|\right)$. Also, determine the conditions under which equality holds. (2006 China Mathematical Olympiad Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_602507 {a b : Fin 3 → ℝ}
  (ha : ∀ i j, a i = a j → i = j)
  (hb : ∀ i j k, (i ≠ j ∧ i ≠ k ∧ j ≠ k) →
    b i = (1 + a i * a j / (a i - a j)) * (1 + a i * a k / (a i - a k))) :
  1 + |a 0 * b 0 + a 1 * b 1 + a 2 * b 2| ≤
  (1 + |a 0|) * (1 + |a 1|) * (1 + |a 2|) ∧
  (1 + |a 0 * b 0 + a 1 * b 1 + a 2 * b 2| =
   (1 + |a 0|) * (1 + |a 1|) * (1 + |a 2|) ↔
   (∀ i, |a i| = 1)) :=

soln_description:

\begin{array}{l}
\text { 4) Let } z_{1} \\
=\cos \alpha \\
+i \sin \alpha, \\
z_{2}=\cos \beta+i \sin \beta, \quad z_{3}=\cos \gamma+i \sin \gamma . \\
\quad \text { It is easy to see that }\left|z_{1}\right|=\left|z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{3}\right|=1,
\end{array}

and from $0 \leqslant \alpha<\beta<\gamma<2 \pi$ we know, $\operatorname{arg} z_{1}=\alpha, \operatorname{arg} z_{2}=\beta, \operatorname{arg} z_{3}=\gamma$, we can get $\beta-\alpha=\gamma-\beta=\frac{2 \pi}{3}$, that is, $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ form an arithmetic sequence.
informal_statement: $\begin{array}{c}\text { Example 2. Given } \sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma=0, \\ \cos \alpha+\cos \beta+\cos \gamma=0, \text { and } 0 \leqslant \alpha< \\ \beta<\gamma<2 \pi \text {. Prove: } \alpha, \beta, \gamma \text { form an arithmetic sequence. }\end{array}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $\begin{array}{c}\text { Example 2. Given } \sin \alpha+\sin \beta+\sin \gamma=0, \\ \cos \alpha+\cos \beta+\cos \gamma=0, \text { and } 0 \leqslant \alpha< \\ \beta<\gamma<2 \pi \text {. Prove: } \alpha, \beta, \gamma \text { form an arithmetic sequence. }\end{array}$ -/
theorem algebra_306686 (α β γ : ℝ) (h₀ : α ∈ Set.Ico 0 (2 * Real.pi)) (h₁ : β ∈ Set.Ico 0 (2 * Real.pi))
    (h₂ : γ ∈ Set.Ico 0 (2 * Real.pi)) (h₃ : α < β ∧ β < γ) (h₄ : Real.sin α + Real.sin β + Real.sin γ = 0)
